urn:contentItem:5315-TBV1-DYG3-11P6-00000-00LOU DOBBS TONIGHT for April 27, 20112011-04-27T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:08:15ZLexisNexisLOU DOBBS TONIGHT7:00 PM ESTJon Hilsenrath, Ann Coulter, Fred Tecce, John Bolton, Walid Phares, Kirsten Powers, Robert Johnson, Ellis Henican, Ron ChristieNEWSFinancial042701cb.229LOU DOBBS TONIGHT for April 27, 2011Lou Dobbs, Peter Barnes, Sandra Smith

LOU DOBBS, FOX BUSINESS HOST: It is Wednesday in America. Federal Reserve Chairman Ben Bernanke makes history, meeting the press for first time in the Reserve's 97 years of existence. Wall Street reacting with a major rally. Our "Market Masters" will join us to tell us what the markets heard, what they like so much, and what will happen next.

Also, Warren Buffett's hand-chosen successor, David Sokol, apparently misled Berkshire Hathaway senior management, according to a company audit.

And tonight, we're going to be talking about Apple, which is a company now denying its so-called iPhones and iPads are spying on users in response to widespread privacy complaints, but now offering a software update to address the situation they say doesn't exist.

Also tonight, the president finally released his birth certificate. What took so long? The president says he now has no time for silliness. He had time however to tape an interview with Oprah. Ann Coulter is among my guests tonight.

And a big shakeup in the president's national security team. Familiar faces going back to the Pentagon and the CIA.

Would you believe the latest addition to the United Nations Human Rights Council is Syria? Former U.S. ambassador to the United Nations, John Bolton, and Dr. Walid Phares join me here.

Those stories and much more coming up on "Lou Dobbs Tonight."

Good evening, everybody. The Federal Reserve today making history, holding the first-ever press conference by a Fed chairman after the Fed announced it would leave interest rates unchanged near zero. The markets welcomed that news and the new transparency with a big rally. The Dow up 95 points, the S&P rose 8, both hitting the highest closing level since 2008. The NASDAQ gained 22 points, hitting its highest close since 2000. The Dow started moving higher immediately after the Fed announced interest rates will remain unchanged. The markets also cheering news the Fed would stop flooding the economy with cash, ending its controversial QE2 policy. The Fed, so far, has bought more than $2 trillion worth of bonds. We'll have complete coverage of the historic press conference by Fed Chairman Ben Bernanke throughout the show.

"FOX Business" senior Washington correspondent, Peter Barnes, was there and, tonight, he's here. "FOX Business's" Sandra Smith with market reaction. "Wall Street Journal" chief economics correspondent, Jon Hilsenrath, will put it in perspective for us.

Let's start with Peter Barnes.

Peter, you were in the big room today. Your thoughts?

PETER BARNES, FOX BUSINESS SENIOR WASHINGTON CORRESPONDENT: At the front table, too, with Jon. And it was just amazing for me, as someone who's covered the Fed for -- on and off for 20 years, Lou. And this press conference came after a meeting of the Fed's policy setting-body today. The Federal Open Market Committee saying that while the economic recovery continues at a moderate pace, growth is still not strong enough and job creation is still lagging. In fact, the FOMC slightly lowered its forecast for economic growth for 2011. The FOMC said it will continue its easy- money policies including keeping short-term interest rates at near zero for the foreseeable future.

It also said it is keeping a close eye on higher food and energy places for signs of inflation problems. But Bernanke said for now the Fed thinks these price increases are temporary because of events in Libya, for example, and should at least start to level off.

Now, part of the Fed's goal of the press conference today was not just to provide more transparency and information about its policy making for anxious consumers and investors, as well as for Congress, but also to show that Bernanke is empathetic to people's every-day struggles and to reassure them

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

BEN BERNANKE, CHAIRMAN, FEDERAL RESERVE: A combination of high unemployment, high gas prices and high foreclosure rates is terrible combination. A lot of people are having a very tough time. So I can certainly understand why people are impatient. I guess the only thing I can say is, while the recovery process looks likely to continue to be a relatively moderate one compared to the depth of the recession, I do think that the pace will pick up over time.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARNES: And in response to a question from Jon Hilsenrath, in fact, Bernanke acknowledged there is not much that the Fed can do about higher energy prices. It can't produce oil or stop rising oil demand from other countries around the world. But he did make it clear, Lou, that higher inflation is the biggest danger for the economy, in the Fed's eyes, and that that would trump job creation in case the Fed had to start raising interest rates to stop any nascent inflation.

DOBBS: Nascent inflation. One would think we --

BARNES: Emerging inflation.

(LAUGHTER)

BARNES: Sorry.

DOBBS: No, no, no. I'm just laughing about the idea of nascent inflation, the idea that we're sitting here with $112 a barrel crude oil. We have $4 gasoline. Food prices are going through the roof. I'm starting to think we may have something beyond nascent. What do you think, Peter?

BARNES: Well, we're still at the core rate which takes out food and energy, which I know still matters for people.

(CROSSTALK)

BARNES: I know. I know it still matters.

DOBBS: They drive, they don't eat.

(LAUGHTER)

BARNES: I know. I know. I know that. I know that.

(LAUGHTER)

DOBBS: Good. I just want to remind you.

BARNES: Core inflation is still just about 1 percent, and headline inflation still around 2 percent.

(CROSSTALK)

DOBBS: OK. I feel better.

BARNES: I know.

(LAUGHTER)

And listen, Bernanke was trying to talk about this to make sure he feels people's pain.

DOBBS: And he did an outstanding job of commiserating as well as communicating.

Peter, thanks so much.

BARNES: OK.

DOBBS: Appreciate it. You did -- you were great.

Peter Barnes.

Well, when Ben Bernanke speaks, the markets react. And we turn now to Sandra Smith to walk us through the day's action on Wall Street.

Quite a day!

SANDRA SMITH, FOX BUSINESS: It was quite a day, Lou. And really, the markets were very sensitive to everything that happened today but, at the end of the day, it was really the perception by the markets that the easy- money policy is going to continue and it was off to the races for the stock market.

Here's a one day look at the Dow Jones Industrial Average. As you can see, we started out pretty volatile. And right about midday, when we got the Fed's announcement, we saw a spike and it climbed all the way into the closing bell, as Ben Bernanke answered all of those questions on inflation. We ended up 95 points on the Dow again. That's the highest levels that we've seen there since 2008 for the Dow. The NASDAQ also gaining, the S&P doing well as well.

But take a look here. This is what we were just chatting about, Lou. Look at all of this green on the screen. These are those big industrial names that, guess what, benefit from a weak U.S. dollar. If you've got that weak dollar, any of these companies that do a lot of overseas sales, General Electric, for example, Verizon, AT&T, big names like Procter & Gamble, they thrive on that weaker dollar. So the market perceived that as a big positive there. And, in fact, only one Dow component finished lower on the day, and that was Cisco Systems. United Technology unchanged on the session.

But I can't let you go yet without taking a look at these commodities. Because, Lou, what a ride it has been. what a ride it continues to be. Bernanke says inflation is contained. Guess what, as he made those comments today, look at crude oil. These are fresh 33-month highs for crude oil, up another buck today, actually the settlement price. This is the GlobeEx (ph) trading. It continues to climb at night. And, Lou, there's gold. Just happens to be another record high in today's session. Silver prices as well.

You still have the safe haven play. You still have the play in the hard asset as long as we have the weaker U.S. dollar, which did, by the way, also fall as we heard Bernanke's comments

DOBBS: And we're getting used to that as well.

SMITH: Yes.

DOBBS: And hopefully, no one will blame that -- today's decline in the dollar on Bernanke, but I suspect they will nonetheless.

Any other sectors that did particularly well today, Sandra?

SMITH: Yes, real quick, if I can get into the sectors, you should note the fact that the banks rallied big-time on all of this news today. They perceived the weak-money policy as good for the financials. We saw a huge rally there. This is between 1 to 3 percent gains for the big banks, but across the board, as far as the sectors are concerned, Lou, big tech rallied. We also saw energy stocks higher on the session. Any of those names like Hewlett-Packard, for example, do a lot of business overseas. Again, it goes back to that story, exports will go up if we continue to devalue the U.S. dollar. But markets are very sensitive to everything coming from the Fed right now.

DOBBS: All right. Sandra, thank you very much. Appreciate it

Well, Jon Hilsenrath, chief economics correspondent for the "Wall Street Journal," also, as Peter and I discussed, at the Fed chairman's historic press conference today.

Jon, great to have you with us.

JON HILSENRATH, CHIEF ECONOMICS CORRESPONDENT, WALL STREET JOURNAL: Thanks for having me.

DOBBS: This -- I have to say, I read so much of the press, not the "Wall Street Journal" certainly, but so much of the press talking about this Fed chairman as if he were going frankly trip coming into the room and be unable to complete any one of his sentences.

HILSENRATH: Yes.

DOBBS: This was, I thought, a bravura, an absolutely bravura performance by the Fed chairman. What was your take?

HILSENRATH: You know, he's very good at this. He's testified before Congress many times. He used to be an undergraduate and graduate professor at Princeton. He spent a lot of time around big brown desks answering questions from other people.

(LAUGHTER)

So I thought he handled himself pretty well.

But I think you and Peter hit upon what's really going to become the big issue for the Fed for the next few months, and that is figuring out how much inflation we have, how serious a problem this is going to be, and when the Fed needs to start raising rates.

He said today, for now, they're on hold. But I can guarantee you there was a very intense discussion in that room the last two days about the inflation outlook, and they're going to be, you know, continuing to battle over that. And I think the market is setting itself up for the Fed gradually unwinding some of these policies, if not the end of this year, early next year.

DOBBS: Jon, personally, I don't think the Fed chairman could have been much clearer. He means to constrain inflation just as every chairperson before him. He's made allowances because of the economy is the markets. And I think --

HILSENRATH: But I thought it was interesting because the Fed's own inflation forecasts are rising and they're not reacting to that.

DOBBS: I would hope.

(LAUGHTER)

I would hope.

HILSENRATH: At least they see what's going on. But they're not reacting to that because they're making a bet right now. They're making a bet that the increase that we've seen in commodities prices is, as they say, transient, that it's not going to hold.

They're also making a bet that the American public believes in the Fed, that the American public believes that the Fed is not going to let inflation get out of control. If commodity prices do keep rising or if the American public loses this faith that the Fed believes it has and starts to expect more inflation, their view might be changing over the course of the next few months.

DOBBS: They might be changing but also the confidence in the Fed, Jon, might also extend to the point that the Fed, in the views of most people, and certainly investors don't believe that the Fed is anywhere near stupid enough to constrain arbitrarily the expansionary monetary policy that it's pursued and put at risk the entire recovery, whether anyone says it has traction or not. It is a delicate one at best, given the Fed's own projection today of 1 percent of first quarter GDP growth, and this sort of -- speaking of temporary -- transitory high energy prices. That's quite a peering into a crystal ball.

HILSENRATH: This is the problem that they have, and this is something that Bernanke said in response to a question that I asked is they're very aware that food and energy prices are rising, especially energy. But you have to think through, well, what would happen if they actually did something about that? If they tried, for instance, to raise interest rates? Maybe energy prices will come down a little bit, but guess what, it is going to hurt the rest of the economy. It could push up unemployment. It could put downward pressure on the American wages. So beating that problem down could actually beat other parts of the economy down too.

DOBBS: Exactly. And that's why I think the Fed has the confidence of a lot of investors right now, is that they know what Ben Bernanke knows.

(LAUGHTER)

And I think Ben Bernanke knows they know it. So let's hope the path towards prosperity is maintained.

Jon, great to have you with us. We appreciate it.

HILSENRATH: All right, thanks.

If you want to comment on Jon's views or any other topic in this broadcast, just e-mail me at Lou@Loudobbs.com

Up next, President Obama has given up his long form -- that's what they call it -- long-form birth certificate. His real birth certificate. He says the controversy was causing him simply too much distraction. The question, I suppose, might be, why didn't he give it to the public sooner? Best-selling author, Ann Coulter, weighs in.

We continue. Please stay with us.

DOBBS: President Obama finally releasing his long-form birth certificate and holding a press conference to address the issue more than two years after he went into office.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

BARACK OBAMA, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: We've got some enormous challenges out there. There are a lot of folks out there who are still looking for work. Everybody is still suffering under high gas prices. We're not going to be able to solve our problems if we get distracted by side shows and carnival barkers.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

DOBBS: The president also issued a challenge to his fellow elected officials, the press and Americans in general to get serious about our nations problems

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

OBAMA: We do not have time for this kind of silliness. We've got better stuff to do. I've got better stuff to do.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

DOBBS: That better stuff started with an afternoon trip to Chicago. He went there to be a guest on the show of one of his biggest backers, Oprah Winfrey, followed by three more -- three -- count them -- more New York city fund-raisers to keep the money flowing into his 2012 reelection coffers, so ostensibly he can finish the work he was apparently distracted by as a result of the long-form birth certificate controversy.

My next guest tonight may be not be a fan of the president's policies or his never, ever, ever ending re-election tour, but she said the constant birther debate is nothing more than a distraction and has been debunked on numerous occasions.

Syndicated columnist and best-selling author, Ann Coulter.

Great to have you with us.

ANN COULTER, SYNDICATED COLUMNIST & AUTHOR: Lou, finally we're at peace.

DOBBS: It's -- finally we're at peace.

(LAUGHTER)

The long-form birth certificate is it.

COULTER: Oh, I wouldn't count on it.

DOBBS: No?

COULTER: I think the hard-core birthers are going to demand proof that Hawaii is a state next.

(LAUGHTER)

DOBBS: Well, now that you mentioned it.

(LAUGHTER)

I just got a kick out of the president today. The man has been accused of being a little politically tone deaf, but this one was a little bizarre because he's telling people to be serious. He can't afford to be distracted.

COULTER: Right.

DOBBS: Apparently, he could afford to be distracted for the previous two years, but then immediately, gets on Air Force One, flies to Chicago to be on Oprah Winfrey's show.

COULTER: No, it's hilarious. And he's in New York at a fund-raiser right now, so I'm just going to stay at FOX all day and keep doing TV shows --

(LAUGHTER)

-- because we cannot move in that traffic out there.

DOBBS: It unfortunately, is absolutely true, the traffic is.

COULTER: Do not knock the fund-raisers and going on Oprah, because if he applies any more of his brilliance and attention to governing, the country could really be in the toilet.

(LAUGHTER)

Every time he's involved, disasters ensue.

DOBBS: Libya a disaster.

COULTER: Right.

DOBBS: Not a stalemate, a disaster.

COULTER: A disaster, as is Afghanistan. What -- to quote liberals on Iraq, what do victories look like in Afghanistan? This is a country that has never exploited terrorism. The Taliban didn't want to attack the U.S. They invited Osama bin Laden in because they wanted to attack the northern alliance.

DOBBS: Right.

COULTER: Bush had accomplished all we were ever going accomplish in Afghanistan before the end of 2001. That was a very important war, but it's over now. What on earth are we doing in Afghanistan? They have more goats than flush toilets.

DOBBS: And have been the target of more drones as well.

COULTER: Right.

DOBBS: At one point or another, it seems to me the United States has to decide whether or not it requires a mission for military conflict. This president is doing nothing to bolster confidence in that view.

COULTER: No. That's right. He's a typical Democrat in this sense, and that is they're all for using the military, provided it serves no U.S. national security interest. Remember, Clinton with Somalia and Bosnia? This guy is sending -- expanded more troops to Afghanistan, to this pointless war, at this point anyway. Keep a few troops there. Keep a few boots on the ground. But why on earth would you be expanding the war there? Libya, Egypt, do we know what we're going to get is better?

DOBBS: So explain to me why the Republicans -- at least some of whom want it appear to be the Republican candidate for president in 2012, are criticizing him for not leading on going into this conflict with Libya? They're not criticizing him because he's put our forces in hostilities with a nation six and a half million people.

COULTER: Right.

DOBBS: They wanted him to be first into it. This is utter madness.

COULTER: No, I don't understand that, except as a knee-jerk reaction to it just being embarrassing to have the French out macho us.

(LAUGHTER)

But I don't even know from what France's interest is. I certainly don't know what our interest is.

DOBBS: They've been diverted by the Ivory Coast.

(LAUGHTER)

COULTER: No, but I would have liked to have seen him take the lead. I'm a bigger supporter of the Iraq War than George Bush is. That served America's interests in like 17 days way. Regime change in Iran, that would be fantastic. And by the way, 18 months ago, when Corneta (ph) was being shot in the streets, peaceful protesters in Iran, that was the video that got shot around YouTube and around the world. We knew what the alternative was. There had jus been an election and Ahmadinejad had lost to the more moderate imam. And you know, why didn't Obama take the lead on that one? No, because that would serve America's interests.

DOBBS: Because there wasn't an Obama doctrine at that point, I believe.

COULTER: Yes. Yes.

DOBBS: That was to be refined later.

COULTER: Yes, the Obama doctrine.

DOBBS: Let me ask you this, what is your next book?

COULTER: Thank you for asking. It comes out June 7th, and I'm going to be right back here, "Lou Dobbs."

DOBBS: You're absolutely going to be here. You're invited, and look forward to it.

COULTER: You're going to love it.

DOBBS: What's the title?

COULTER: The title is "Demonic, How the Liberal Mobs are Endangering America."

(LAUGHTER)

DOBBS: I love this. I love it.

COULTER: And it will knock your socks off

(LAUGHTER)

DOBBS: All right. Ann Coulter, thanks for being here.

COULTER: Thank you

DOBBS: Up next, the Supreme Court hands down a major victory for American business. That story and a lot more in tonight's "RoundUp."

And later here, former ambassador to the United Nations, John Bolton, and "FOX terrorism analyst, Dr. Walid Phares. They weigh in on the war that is not a war, but is still raging nonetheless in Libya.

We continue in one moment. Stay with us.

DOBBS: A developing story tonight. A critical decision from the Supreme Court. It is seen as a key victory for American business. Voting 5-4 along ideological lines, the nation's highest court has ruled that AT&T can require its customers to arbitrate their disputes individually instead of through class-action lawsuits. That essentially makes it far more difficult for dissatisfied customers to ban together against businesses.

Joining us now, former federal prosecutor, Fred Tecce.

Good to have you with us, Fred.

FRED TECCE, FORMER FEDERAL PROSECUTOR: Hey, Lou. Thank you very much for having me.

DOBBS: That is quite a decision. Effectively -- I mean, does this mean the end of class-action law suits?

TECCE: No, it doesn't. But what it may mean, Lou, is the end of the cases like the one you saw in this case, where the plaintiffs were suing for basically $30. When you really look at these cases, Lou, they're really nothing more than the lawyers Fair Employment Act. What really ends up happening is AT&T gets defended by some big Wall Street firm for a million dollars a month and they drag the case through three years of discovery. When the case settles, the plaintiffs' lawyers put in for attorneys fees. They don't want to be outdone by the defendant so they ask for $15, $20 million and the class members, people like this couple who lost $30, get a voucher for $30 worth of phone service going forward with AT&T or a free AT&T T-shirts.

(LAUGHTER)

So at the end, of the day these types of cases -- these types of cases are really not that significant. You have to understand something. The Federal Arbitration Act has been around since 1925, and it's been there for reasons such as this. There's strong public policies encouraging arbitration.

Now, the trial lawyer in me, the plaintiff's lawyer in me, I always want to be in front of the jury. I want my case decided by 12 people --

DOBBS: With that cash register ringing, right?

TECCE: That's right. That's right -- by 12 people who are too civic minded to get out of jury duty. And you know why, Lou? There's no such thing as a runaway arbitration. Never been one yet. This is why -- arbitration does have benefits. It's more balanced.

And you know, interestingly, what struck me about this case is we're waiting for the Supreme Court to rule in the Wal-Mart case on the sexual harassment case --

DOBBS: Right.

TECCE: -- and sexual discrimination, and this could be a harbinger of what is going to happen in that case as well.

DOBBS: That's a very important point. And like so many people -- I mean, I've been a part of class-action lawsuits but without ever knowing it. And I get --

TECCE: Oh, so have I.

DOBBS: And being told I could pick up my $3.11 at some point. It's time for the -- I know it is against their economic interest, but it's time for legal profession in this country to be -- if I may suggest this, to be somewhat constrained in their appetite and lust for money. Just think --

TECCE: Well, I think they need to be -- right. I think lawyers need to be circumspect. I'm sorry. These kind of cases -- even when I was in law school, which was so long ago, we studied by candlelight -- I mean, my civil procedures professor used to talk about these things. He used to say put a clothes pin on your nose because the only people who make money, this thing stinks so bad, are the lawyers.

DOBBS: Right.

TECCE: And I think these are the kind of cases that I think should be limited. So I -- we --

DOBBS: Some light and some deodorant here from the Supreme Court.

TECCE: Correct. Correct. Correct.

DOBBS: Fred, we appreciate it a lot. Thanks very much.

TECCE: Thanks for having me.

DOBBS: Fred Tecce.

Well, in the "RoundUp" tonight, Berkshire Hathaway saying its former executive, David Sokol, once considered a successor, if not the successor to Warren Buffett, according to a board audit, violated company ethics policies when he bought shares of the chemical company, Lubrizol. Sokol resigned in March after it emerged that he had personally bought some $10 million of the stock, before bringing the company to the attention of Warren Buffett. Berkshire later agreed to buy Lubrizol, causing a surge in the value of Sokol's holdings to increase by some $3 million. Berkshire said it is still considering the possibility of legal action against Sokol and will cooperate with any possible government investigation.

After a week of silence, Apple is responding to widespread consumer complaints about iPhones and iPads that track their user's whereabouts. In a statement today, Apple denied spying on users or following their locations, and then promised to release a software update in the next few weeks to address the situation that it had just denied exists. That update will reduce the amount of data stored on iPhones and will delete location information entirely when a user chooses to switch off location services on the device as many thought it would already.

Earlier today Britain's royal couple in Westminster Abbey are there for the final wedding rehearsal before the big day -- Friday, if you've forgotten. As the world counts down to the royal ceremony book makers are gearing up to cash in on the event. Gamblers in the U.K. have already been wagering on everything from the color of the queen's hat to whether Kate Middleton will leave Prince William at the altar.

In all, bookings are expected to take more than a million and half dollars of what has been dubbed the "wedding of the century."

Up next, one of my next guests warns President Obama risks a Vietnam style quagmire in Libya because of his indecision on the time-limited and scope-limited military action. Ambassador John Bolton and Professor Walid Phares join me next. We're coming right back.

DOBBS: Republicans tonight accusing President Obama of playing politics by releasing his long form birth certificate today instead of focusing on the economy. At this hour President Obama is delivering remarks at one of three fundraisers he's attending here in New York, his third trip here in less than a month, and money the focus of all of those trips.

Stocks today rising after fed chairman Ben Bernanke said he expects the nation's moderate economic recovery to continue through the year. Bernanke's comments came during his first ever, the Fed's first ever news conference following a two day policy meeting on the direction of interest rates.

Tomorrow we're expecting remarks from the president about personnel changes on his national security team. And sources in the administration say the president is planning to name CIA Director Leon Panetta as the next secretary of defense succeeding Robert Gates. General David Petraeus, who is now running the war in Afghanistan, would move to the top job at the CIA.

Joining me now to an assess this shakeup and what it could mean for U.S. policy, former U.N. ambassador John Bolton, FOX News contributor, and Dr. Walid Phares, FOX News Middle Eastern affairs analyst and author of the book "The Coming Revolution -- Struggle for Freedom in the Middle East." Gentlemen, thanks for being here.

Ambassador, let me start with you. What do you think of the idea of Leon Panetta at defense?

JOHN BOLTON, FORMER U.S. AMBASSADOR TO THE U.N.: Well, I think it would not represent any substantial change in policy. I think the president has confidence in Leon Panetta's discretion. And at one point here you know the relationship between Secretary of Defense Gates and Secretary of State Clinton has been very, very close. This famous New Yorker article that talks about Clinton, talks about Obama's leading from behind strategy points out that Secretary Clinton basically just sided with secretary of defense gates on most key issues.

Panetta is of course former chief of staff for President Clinton so. So the relationship between Secretary Clinton and Secretary Panetta may be very close. And I think that's what Obama wants. He doesn't want discord between those two top jobs.

DOBBS: God forbid discord, Professor Phares. This administration is it seems utterly committed to the Clinton administration.

DR. WALID PHARES, FOX NEWS MIDDLE EAST ANALYST: Well, in a sense these changes that we see right now if they show anything, they show the next stage which is not Clinton strategy or inspired by that which is to transform the fight with the appointment of General Petraeus to the head of the CIA from classical confrontation of the Taliban to one led by the CIA with the military head, which means is in preparation for major change of strategy in the region.

DOBBS: Gentleman, I understand David Petraeus has many fans in Washington, particularly in the Republican Party, but his accomplishments in Afghanistan are unremarkable, are they not? I'm sorry, ambassador you first?

BOLTON: Sorry. I think this is a way of sidelining Petraeus. From his career you would expect the next step up would be as chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff when Admiral Mullen steps down after the end of his second term this fall. Chairman of the joint chiefs is a very high- profile position. Certainly director of the CIA is very significant too, but not nearly as high-profile. I think this is another safe bet by the Obama White House.

DOBBS: Well, this Obama White House not making many safe bets as you put it in the Middle East or Northern Africa. Walid, give us your view as to what is going to be the disposition in Libya? Everyone I've talked to, and I think I can say this accurately without exception has said we're looking at a stalemate

PHARES: There is a stalemate right now and I call it such since neither, Gadhafi was able to take over Benghazi, that's a fact, or the opposition is not even able to cross the line in the center of Libya. The problem in that case is that over the past weeks we understood who the foe is, that's Gadhafi. We want to remove him.

But there are a lot of things we are not clear about. One is what is the composition of the opposition. We keep repeating this. We are partnering with an opposition we don't know much about. The suggestion is to invite that government to Washington to ask them questions. What is the end, endgame, meaning what will happen basically after Gadhafi is over. So it could consent to all these sacrifices.

DOBBS: Walid Phares, John Bolton we thank you both for being with us. We appreciate it.

BOLTON: Thank you.

DOBBS: Up next, radical new ideas about reinventing the U.S. economy. Robert Johnston, executive director of the Institute for New Economic Thinking will be here.

And don't forget to join us on the Lou Dobbs radio show each and every day on stations all across America. Go to loudobbs.com to get the station in your area or click listen live on loudobbs.com to listen over the Internet. We're coming right back.

DOBBS: My next guest hosted the Bretton Woods conference earlier this month. He says something has to be done about the lack of trust in government and our markets. Robert Johnston is the executive director of the Institute for New Economic Thinking. Robert, it's good to see you here.

Ben Bernanke today breaking with history, creating history by talking openly and I thought very candidly with the American people and the press. What did you think?

ROBERT JOHNSON, INSTITUTE FOR NEW ECONOMIC THINKING: I thought Ben Bernanke did a very good job today but he's talking in order to rebuild the trust of the American people in the Federal Reserve. The Fed has a lot of work to do to regain everyone's trust.

DOBBS: Specifically I think most people were a little astonished that the Fed refused to tell Congress to whom it had lent if you prefer, money. It turns out most of that money had gone to foreign banks under quantitative easing putting some $2.5 trillion to work in the financial system, pure injection of a capital into the system.

Without that, one has the feeling that we would be in quite different and frankly poorer circumstances without his leadership.

JOHNSON: Yes, I think he improvised well. But as you said when say, after the Dodd-Frank Bill they revealed all of these problems. You saw how much the Fed hadn't done in preventative maintenance in five years before and they also stalled. They should have provided that information before Dodd-Frank was made, not after.

DOBBS: Dodd-Frank, is it worth the paper it was written on?

JOHNSON: Just barely.

DOBBS: Barely? OK. Well, we'll find out what it really means. Dodd-Frank quantitative easing all of this is controversial. This Fed, this chairman Ben Bernanke being blamed for a weak dollar, being blamed for inflationary foundation through the monetary expansion of policies of this Fed.

What in the world -- what in the world do you think is the reason he is the lightning rod for all of this because one man no matter how powerful the so-called second most powerful man in Washington he couldn't possibly be responsible for all that has gone awry in this country over the last decade.

JOHNSON: Lou, there's an old saying -- when a system breaks like it did in 2008, either the people are good and the system's bad, and Dodd Frank didn't repair the system, or the system's OK and the people are bad.

The American people are angry. They're angry, they're upset about what happened and they look for scapegoats. And Bernanke who said last year economic theory is OK, which I disagree with. That's why we have an Institute for New Economic Thinking. He isn't really telling people what went wrong and he's trying to get back on track. He's trying to do the right thing.

DOBBS: I feel, I've got to be honest with you. Let me say this clearly. I don't think Bernanke is the problem. I don't think the system is the problem. I think a bunch of frankly intellectually limited elected representatives in Congress and the Senate and frankly the White House are responsible for $14 trillion in debt responsible for $113 in unfunded liabilities, $7 trillion in trade debt, and to hang that on one fed chairman seems grossly unfair.

JOHNSON: As a matter of fact, when the Congress was unwilling to address the problems they had made in financial regulation and do the bailout, Bernanke had to do the things that were revealed thereafter. He actually stopped us from going off the waterfall.

DOBBS: Are we safe now?

JOHNSON: No.

DOBBS: What's next?

JOHNSON: It's probably not right on the cusp, but our financial system is not based on real theories. It's like a navigator. The ship hit the rocks our charts are bad. We have to remake the charts.

DOBBS: What are first two things we ought to do?

JOHNSON: The first thing we ought to do is stop this too big to fail nonsense at the large banks which are essentially ungovernable.

DOBBS: Ungovernable, and whether they're too big to fail or not. They sure seem to be too big to regulate, don't they? Can it be fixed?

JOHNSON: I think it could be fixed but a different kind of politics that we have right now.

DOBBS: OK. You know what we're going to do, come back soon. We'll talk about the politics of fixing it. We'll talk about some of the solutions. It's about sometime we got a few in this country. The president even gave up his long form birth certificate. Maybe we can fix a couple problems in banking. Rob Johnson thanks for being here.

JOHNSON: My pleasure.

DOBBS: Up next we'll ask our A-Team what they think of the timing of the president's birth certificate release shortly before he departed for three fundraisers in New York and a guest appearance on Oprah. He wouldn't want to be distracted now, mind you. We're coming right back.

DOBBS: "Lou Dobbs Tonight" A-Team is here, Ellis Henican, columnist for "Newsday," FOX News contributor, Ron Christi, Republican strategist, Kirsten Powers, "New York Post" columnist FOX News political analyst. Thank you all for being here.

Kirsten, let's begin with you because I have to believe that the nation's capital is just reverberating with shock, surprise, and delight at the president's long form birth certificate.

KIRSTEN POWERS, COLUMNIST, "NEW YORK POST": It certainly kept us all busy today. I was very surprised that they did it and not sure it would have been what I recommended that they do.

DOBBS: Really?

POWERS: Really for a couple reasons. One is I think that politically it worked to Obama's benefit by having the Republican sort of distracted with something that really I think most people thought is a very peripheral issue. They're talking about that instead of talking about where the jobs or other things actually people care about. So I think it is something that is also making Donald Trump look like kind of a buffoon. Why get in between your opponent when they're harming themselves? I don't really understand that.

DOBBS: Well, Ellis, tell us what you think?

ELLIS HENICAN, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: I think Kirsten is on to something there.

DOBBS: Congratulations, Kirsten.

HENICAN: I agree. Listen, the Obama strategy, think about this in electoral terms.

DOBBS: Now you're going to make it complicated.

HENICAN: Unfortunately, Lou, it does have something do with politics.

DOBBS: I'm going write notes.

HENICAN: But listen, the Democratic strategy right now is make the Republicans seem wacky and extreme.

DOBBS: Oh, that's why they keep calling it extreme.

HENICAN: The word gets mentioned, so the more Sarah Palin is upfront, the more Congresswoman Bachmann is given air time, the more Donald Trump is stomping around New Hampshire.

DOBBS: The higher Obama's ratings go in the polls, is that right?

HENICAN: So what we had here with this birth certificate is they just dragged it out just about as long as they could. Finally at some point you have to put the paper out, and I think by today we kind of reach that point.

DOBBS: Are you dazzled by this analysis?

RON CHRISTIE, REPUBLICAN STRATEGIST: Dazzled by the fact that the Democrats seem to think their strategy should be to make the Republicans look bad other than governing.

(CROSSTALK)

But this is ridiculous. If the president had his birth certificate and saw this issue before him before why not put it out there. To let this drag out and drag on -- of course he's in New York City today doing fund- raisers and jet offing to do Oprah. But we're not distracted. Now think the story will live on longer than it would have.

DOBBS: Let's find out how the story on Libya will last. It was supposed to last only days and Kirsten we are now well into our sixth week here. At what point is there going to be some sort of coalesce sense around the fact that this is a serious foreign policy issue of the United States. The Republican leadership is going to have something to say and this president going to start talk about his policy in the Middle East and northern Africa.

POWERS: I certainly would hope so but I want to say the whole Obama should have put the birth certificate thing out a bit of a canard because the reality is what was released is what Hawaii traditionally releases. Their law says that they don't release what Obama released today. And the White House had to go and ask to help overrule that law. So I don't know why the president needs to do stuff like that.

But moving on to Libya, look, I was completely against the intervention.

DOBBS: Let me ask you a question -- I just asked you about Libya which I consider to be a relatively important topic. You call it a canard and want to reassert into it the conversation. I'm just curious about that?

POWERS: I've been hearing it all day long and it's something -

DOBBS: So I'm being held responsible for -

POWERS: No, no. It's not your fault, but I'm just saying people need to understand that it's not -- this is not Obama's fault.

DOBBS: Why not. All he had to do was release it two years ago and it was done.

POWERS: No, no. It's not Obama's fault.

(LAUGHTER)

No president has ever had to release their birth certificate. Lou, come on, how many presidents had to release their birth certificates to prove they're legitimate? That's what we're talking about here and I don't think he should have ever been expected to do this.

HENICAN: With the risk of dragging the conversation in the gutter do you want to talk about Libya or something?

(LAUGHTER)

DOBBS: I made a good faith, wholehearted effort. Where would you like to take us?

HENICAN: No, I mean, listen, in the Libya thing there is a lesson that would be nice if we would learn is these things once we get in that they're hard to get out. And that was a problem in Iraq and Afghanistan and it seems despite the limited focus of the mission in Libya, it is likely to be a problem. It would be nice if we learn that before we do this three, four more times.

POWERS: Also it would have been nice if you got congressional approval for it.

CHRISTIE: Again, on a day that we have so many serious issues to deal with -- we have a debt limit coming up. We need significant cuts in spending need to be responsible about the size and scope of the government we're talking about the president's birth certificate, Libya with an undefined mission. These guys need to get serious.

DOBBS: I would like to also throw in the possibility that this country is starting to take seriously the decision it takes when we decide to kill people in foreign lands. Thank you very much, Ellis. Thank you so much, Kirsten, and thank you, Ron. Good to see you.

Up next, I'll have a few not-so-random thoughts about Ben Bernanke's performance at his historic news conference today.

DOBBS: Congratulations to Fed Chairman Ben Bernanke on his performance today. He was forthright, clear and for an economist to the point.

To read much of the nation's business press, however, you would have been forgiven for thinking the Fed chairman would today be a complete bumbler, lucky to get through the press conference without breaking out in a sweat of incoherent incompetent, and through his sheer inability to comprehend markets and banking and thereby send world markets into chaos.

It really doesn't matter much your politics, your ideology, whether you're for a strong dollar, whether you believe in the central bank or want to abolish it. You have to applaud the Fed chairman not simply for one day's historic press conference but for doing one hell of a job as chairman of the Fed. We should have such bumblers throughout our government. Thanks, Mr. Chairman.

That's it for "Lou Dobbs Tonight." Please join us here tomorrow. Judge Andrew Napolitano will be with us, and he has the show next. Goodnight from New York.

LOU DOBBS, FOX BUSINESS HOST: It is Wednesday in America. Federal Reserve Chairman Ben Bernanke makes history, meeting the press for first time in the Reserve's 97 years of existence. Wall Street reacting with a major rally. Our "Market Masters" will join us to tell us what the markets heard, what they like so much, and what will happen next.

Also, Warren Buffett's hand-chosen successor, David Sokol, apparently misled Berkshire Hathaway senior management, according to a company audit.

And tonight, we're going to be talking about Apple, which is a company now denying its so-called iPhones and iPads are spying on users in response to widespread privacy complaints, but now offering a software update to address the situation they say doesn't exist.

Also tonight, the president finally released his birth certificate. What took so long? The president says he now has no time for silliness. He had time however to tape an interview with Oprah. Ann Coulter is among my guests tonight.

And a big shakeup in the president's national security team. Familiar faces going back to the Pentagon and the CIA.

Would you believe the latest addition to the United Nations Human Rights Council is Syria? Former U.S. ambassador to the United Nations, John Bolton, and Dr. Walid Phares join me here.

Those stories and much more coming up on "Lou Dobbs Tonight."

Good evening, everybody. The Federal Reserve today making history, holding the first-ever press conference by a Fed chairman after the Fed announced it would leave interest rates unchanged near zero. The markets welcomed that news and the new transparency with a big rally. The Dow up 95 points, the S&P rose 8, both hitting the highest closing level since 2008. The NASDAQ gained 22 points, hitting its highest close since 2000. The Dow started moving higher immediately after the Fed announced interest rates will remain unchanged. The markets also cheering news the Fed would stop flooding the economy with cash, ending its controversial QE2 policy. The Fed, so far, has bought more than $2 trillion worth of bonds. We'll have complete coverage of the historic press conference by Fed Chairman Ben Bernanke throughout the show.

It turns out most of that money had gone to foreign banks under quantitative easing putting some $2.5 trillion to work in the financial system, pure injection of a capital into the system.

Without that, one has the feeling that we would be in quite different and frankly poorer circumstances without his leadership.

JOHNSON: Yes, I think he improvised well. But as you said when say, after the Dodd-Frank Bill they revealed all of these problems. You saw how much the Fed hadn't done in preventative maintenance in five years before and they also stalled. They should have provided that information before Dodd-Frank was made, not after.

DOBBS: Dodd-Frank, is it worth the paper it was written on?

JOHNSON: Just barely.

DOBBS: Barely? OK. Well, we'll find out what it really means. Dodd-Frank quantitative easing all of this is controversial. This Fed, this chairman Ben Bernanke being blamed for a weak dollar, being blamed for inflationary foundation through the monetary expansion of policies of this Fed.

What in the world -- what in the world do you think is the reason he is the lightning rod for all of this because one man no matter how powerful the so-called second most powerful man in Washington he couldn't possibly be responsible for all that has gone awry in this country over the last decade.

JOHNSON: Lou, there's an old saying -- when a system breaks like it did in 2008, either the people are good and the system's bad, and Dodd Frank didn't repair the system, or the system's OK and the people are bad.

The American people are angry. They're angry, they're upset about what happened and they look for scapegoats. And Bernanke who said last year economic theory is OK, which I disagree with. That's why we have an Institute for New Economic Thinking. He isn't really telling people what went wrong and he's trying to get back on track. He's trying to do the right thing.

DOBBS: I feel, I've got to be honest with you. Let me say this clearly. I don't think Bernanke is the problem. I don't think the system is the problem. I think a bunch of frankly intellectually limited elected representatives in Congress and the Senate and frankly the White House are responsible for $14 trillion in debt responsible for $113 in unfunded liabilities, $7 trillion in trade debt, and to hang that on one fed chairman seems grossly unfair.

JOHNSON: As a matter of fact, when the Congress was unwilling to address the problems they had made in financial regulation and do the bailout, Bernanke had to do the things that were revealed thereafter. He actually stopped us from going off the waterfall.

DOBBS: Are we safe now?

JOHNSON: No.

DOBBS: What's next?

JOHNSON: It's probably not right on the cusp, but our financial system is not based on real theories. It's like a navigator. The ship hit the rocks our charts are bad. We have to remake the charts.

DOBBS: What are first two things we ought to do?

JOHNSON: The first thing we ought to do is stop this too big to fail nonsense at the large banks which are essentially ungovernable.

DOBBS: Ungovernable, and whether they're too big to fail or not. They sure seem to be too big to regulate, don't they? Can it be fixed?

JOHNSON: I think it could be fixed but a different kind of politics that we have right now.

DOBBS: OK. You know what we're going to do, come back soon. We'll talk about the politics of fixing it. We'll talk about some of the solutions. It's about sometime we got a few in this country. The president even gave up his long form birth certificate. Maybe we can fix a couple problems in banking. Rob Johnson thanks for being here.

JOHNSON: My pleasure.

DOBBS: Up next we'll ask our A-Team what they think of the timing of the president's birth certificate release shortly before he departed for three fundraisers in New York and a guest appearance on Oprah. He wouldn't want to be distracted now, mind you. We're coming right back.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

DOBBS: "Lou Dobbs Tonight" A-Team is here, Ellis Henican, columnist for "Newsday," FOX News contributor, Ron Christi, Republican strategist, Kirsten Powers, "New York Post" columnist FOX News political analyst. Thank you all for being here.

Kirsten, let's begin with you because I have to believe that the nation's capital is just reverberating with shock, surprise, and delight at the president's long form birth certificate.

KIRSTEN POWERS, COLUMNIST, "NEW YORK POST": It certainly kept us all busy today. I was very surprised that they did it and not sure it would have been what I recommended that they do.

DOBBS: Really?

POWERS: Really for a couple reasons. One is I think that politically it worked to Obama's benefit by having the Republican sort of distracted with something that really I think most people thought is a very peripheral issue. They're talking about that instead of talking about where the jobs or other things actually people care about. So I think it is something that is also making Donald Trump look like kind of a buffoon. Why get in between your opponent when they're harming themselves? I don't really understand that.

DOBBS: Well, Ellis, tell us what you think?

ELLIS HENICAN, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: I think Kirsten is on to something there.

DOBBS: Congratulations, Kirsten.

HENICAN: I agree. Listen, the Obama strategy, think about this in electoral terms.

DOBBS: Now you're going to make it complicated.

HENICAN: Unfortunately, Lou, it does have something do with politics.

DOBBS: I'm going write notes.

HENICAN: But listen, the Democratic strategy right now is make the Republicans seem wacky and extreme.

DOBBS: Oh, that's why they keep calling it extreme.

HENICAN: The word gets mentioned, so the more Sarah Palin is upfront, the more Congresswoman Bachmann is given air time, the more Donald Trump is stomping around New Hampshire.

DOBBS: The higher Obama's ratings go in the polls, is that right?

HENICAN: So what we had here with this birth certificate is they just dragged it out just about as long as they could. Finally at some point you have to put the paper out, and I think by today we kind of reach that point.

DOBBS: Are you dazzled by this analysis?

RON CHRISTIE, REPUBLICAN STRATEGIST: Dazzled by the fact that the Democrats seem to think their strategy should be to make the Republicans look bad other than governing.

(CROSSTALK)

But this is ridiculous. If the president had his birth certificate and saw this issue before him before why not put it out there. To let this drag out and drag on -- of course he's in New York City today doing fund- raisers and jet offing to do Oprah. But we're not distracted. Now think the story will live on longer than it would have.

DOBBS: Let's find out how the story on Libya will last. It was supposed to last only days and Kirsten we are now well into our sixth week here. At what point is there going to be some sort of coalesce sense around the fact that this is a serious foreign policy issue of the United States. The Republican leadership is going to have something to say and this president going to start talk about his policy in the Middle East and northern Africa.

POWERS: I certainly would hope so but I want to say the whole Obama should have put the birth certificate thing out a bit of a canard because the reality is what was released is what Hawaii traditionally releases. Their law says that they don't release what Obama released today. And the White House had to go and ask to help overrule that law. So I don't know why the president needs to do stuff like that.

But moving on to Libya, look, I was completely against the intervention.

DOBBS: Let me ask you a question -- I just asked you about Libya which I consider to be a relatively important topic. You call it a canard and want to reassert into it the conversation. I'm just curious about that?

POWERS: I've been hearing it all day long and it's something -

DOBBS: So I'm being held responsible for -

POWERS: No, no. It's not your fault, but I'm just saying people need to understand that it's not -- this is not Obama's fault.

DOBBS: Why not. All he had to do was release it two years ago and it was done.

POWERS: No, no. It's not Obama's fault.

(LAUGHTER)

No president has ever had to release their birth certificate. Lou, come on, how many presidents had to release their birth certificates to prove they're legitimate? That's what we're talking about here and I don't think he should have ever been expected to do this.

HENICAN: With the risk of dragging the conversation in the gutter do you want to talk about Libya or something?

(LAUGHTER)

DOBBS: I made a good faith, wholehearted effort. Where would you like to take us?

HENICAN: No, I mean, listen, in the Libya thing there is a lesson that would be nice if we would learn is these things once we get in that they're hard to get out. And that was a problem in Iraq and Afghanistan and it seems despite the limited focus of the mission in Libya, it is likely to be a problem. It would be nice if we learn that before we do this three, four more times.

POWERS: Also it would have been nice if you got congressional approval for it.

CHRISTIE: Again, on a day that we have so many serious issues to deal with -- we have a debt limit coming up. We need significant cuts in spending need to be responsible about the size and scope of the government we're talking about the president's birth certificate, Libya with an undefined mission. These guys need to get serious.

DOBBS: I would like to also throw in the possibility that this country is starting to take seriously the decision it takes when we decide to kill people in foreign lands. Thank you very much, Ellis. Thank you so much, Kirsten, and thank you, Ron. Good to see you.

Up next, I'll have a few not-so-random thoughts about Ben Bernanke's performance at his historic news conference today.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

DOBBS: Congratulations to Fed Chairman Ben Bernanke on his performance today. He was forthright, clear and for an economist to the point.

To read much of the nation's business press, however, you would have been forgiven for thinking the Fed chairman would today be a complete bumbler, lucky to get through the press conference without breaking out in a sweat of incoherent incompetent, and through his sheer inability to comprehend markets and banking and thereby send world markets into chaos.

It really doesn't matter much your politics, your ideology, whether you're for a strong dollar, whether you believe in the central bank or want to abolish it. You have to applaud the Fed chairman not simply for one day's historic press conference but for doing one hell of a job as chairman of the Fed. We should have such bumblers throughout our government. Thanks, Mr. Chairman.

That's it for "Lou Dobbs Tonight." Please join us here tomorrow. Judge Andrew Napolitano will be with us, and he has the show next. Goodnight from New York.

END

urn:contentItem:5R24-5YB1-JCJY-G0CW-00000-00LoveFilm and Citymapper backer Balderton on hunt for Europe's next tech giant2017-11-27T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:08:15ZLexisNexisBUSINESSVersion:1LoveFilm and Citymapper backer Balderton on hunt for Europe's next tech giantBy Jack Torrance

One of London's best-known venture capital firms has raised a new $375m (£281m) fund as it goes on the hunt for Europe's answer to Google, Amazon or Facebook.

Balderton Capital, which has backed the likes of LoveFilm, Citymapper and Wonga, said the Continent's technology sector had reached a "pivotal moment" that could produce a company with the scale to rival the Silicon Valley giants.

Suranga Chandratillake, a partner at Balderton, told The Daily Telegraph that, while it was hard to predict what area of tech the next giant would come from, artificial intelligence "looks like a pretty good bet".

He said: "Many of the best research departments are based on this Continent. Many of the best students, wherever they're from in the world, come through that system, and many of those people want to stay here."

Balderton, the venture capital firm which backed various online businesses including Wonga, is on the search for Europe's next big tech giant

Mr Chandratillake said Balderton's sixth fund, its first since 2014, had ­attracted new backers from the US and the firm's first investor from Asia, as global institutions clamoured for a slice of Europe's burgeoning tech scene.

That's partly a reflection of how the Continent's start-up "ecosystem" has improved, said Mr Chandratillake, but is also because VC firms can pay less for higher equity stakes than they would in the US.

The sector has benefited from improved regulations and government support, he said, but the biggest boost has come from a decline in the popularity of finance and civil service jobs since the financial crisis.

"Banking is a lot less attractive to a generation of millennials who question exactly how the banks do what they do," he said.

"At the same time, there was this ­ascendancy of technology entrepreneurship and this idea that, actually, this is something where you can be successful, you can make money, but you can also feel that you're actually doing something for good."

Balderton, which typically makes ­investments of £3m to £7m, has $2.6m under management and has backed 10 companies since March.

Don't tell anyone, but my iPhone charger is hidden under some newspapers on my desk so that it's less likely to go walkies when I'm not there.

I've always taken precautions, with people very eager to “borrow” this vital energy supply, and in future, I may have to bolt my chargers to the desk. The European Union just doubled the chances of me losing them this week when it revived the idea of universal chargers that would fit Apple, Samsung and any other smartphones.

Apart from the extra jeopardy I will face personally, the tech industry's own selfish interests are in focus here. “The EU-enforced common charger is the enemy of progress” was the headline of a release from the   corporate-backed Consumer Choice Center, which said any such move would undermine innovation and restrict competition. It   echoed the argument when this last came up from Apple, which is the king of proprietary technologies and whose Lightning connectors are still cursed by anyone wanting to plug in a headphone jack.

I don't buy their concerns. Where would we be without common USB and HDMI standards, and WiFi and Bluetooth, all with dongle-less backwards compatibility? I would happily trade a little innovation and commercial advantage for those invaluable conformities. 

Of course, legislators are always behind the tech curve and the common charger debate would become moot if we all bought wireless charging mats that removed the need for hard connections completely. Then again, some companies are not being as innovative in taking us to that bright new future as they think they are. Apple announced its AirPower wireless charging mats in 2017, but had to cancel the product less than two years later after struggling to make one that worked properly.

The Internet of (Five) Things

1. Microsoft's carbon dating
The software shop has gone further than other tech giants in committing to become  “carbon negative” by 2030  and offset all carbon emissions made since it was founded. The $1.2tn company also announced a $1bn innovation fund to tackle the climate crisis.

2. There's another trillion-dollar tech titan
Alphabet on Thursday became the fourth Big Tech company to  reach a market capitalisation of $1tn. Apple was the first public company  to achieve the milestone, in August 2018, and is now more than a third of the way to a second trillion. It was followed by Amazon, which has since fallen back below the 13-digit threshold, and then Microsoft. Meanwhile, Tesla's soaring share price is giving short sellers the heebie jeebies.

3. Peacock proud of its free streaming strategy
The last major streaming debut is also the cheapest. Comcast unveiled its NBCUniversal Peacock streaming service on Thursday and said it would be free for its existing cable customers when it launches fully in July. There will be live sports and news, a large catalogue of older sitcoms, and the service will primarily rely on advertising rather than the subscriptions favoured by rivals. “We like the idea of zigging when others zag,” said NBCUniversal chairman Steve Burke.

Sign up here with one click

4. WhatsApp won't rely on ads
Facebook is dropping plans to show ads on its WhatsApp messaging service, according to a report by the  Wall Street Journal. WhatsApp disbanded the team working on integrating ads on to the platform recently and even the code they had created was deleted from the app.

5. Ad industry faces wrath of regulator
The UK’s data protection regulator is braced to do battle with the country’s £13bn online advertising industry, saying it will start investigating individual companies that are in breach of European data protection law and enforcing it against them. The Information Commissioner's Office said the ad industry had responded insufficiently to a six-month grace period to get its house in order.

Tech tools — Logitech’s K860 ergonomic keyboard

The peripherals maker is putting wrist comfort front and centre with the $130 K860 launched this week   .   Engadget says it has a split design with the keys angled to align with your wrists, putting less strain on them along with forearms, and consequently making your hands, neck and shoulders more relaxed. It comes with an integrated curved wrist rest with pillowed cushioning and should pair well with   its vertical mouse.

urn:contentItem:5W82-12T1-DXJR-H192-00000-00'Low Chance of Global Recession'2019-06-03T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:08:15ZLexisNexisFRONT PAGE'Low Chance of Global Recession'Arijit.Barman@timesgroup.com

Digitisation of Indian economy to create opportunities, FDI inflows to gather pace if reforms continue, says Solomon

ET EXCLUSIVE

The re-election of Prime Minister Narendra Modi with a massive mandate has been a major confidence booster for Goldman Sachs in India, both as an investor and as an allocator of capital, said its top executive, and hoped for the continuation of economic reforms.

“Our base case on GDP growth is 7.5%,” said Goldman Sachs CEO David M Solomon in his first interview with Indian media. “If the reform programme accelerates there can be considerable upside in the GDP growth on a forward basis… Our growth will closely match that of the growth of the Indian economy.”

In a freewheeling conversation with ET over video conference, Solomon spoke on a wide range of topics that impact global finance and corporates, touching upon issues as diverse as economic reforms in India, the timing of a possible global recession, the future path of US interest rates, global trade wars as well as the desirability of breaking up Big Tech firms like Facebook.

The former chief operating officer of the bank, who took over last October from Lloyd Blankfein, the legendary risk titan, believes India is going to need significant amounts of capital — an area where the Wall Street bellwether can play a key role. “If you think about the continuing digitisation of the economy in India, obviously that's going to create many opportunities.” The reforms process, if continued under the new government, will further accelerate FDI inflows, he said.

The new $250 million, 1.2 million square foot Bengaluru office, which was inaugurated last Thursday and will serve as a global centre supporting innovation, represents Goldman's confidence in India's long-term potential.

The ongoing trade war between the US and China has opened up new opportunities as global supply chains are being tweaked as companies seek to reduce their dependence on China. However, based on interactions with top CEOs, he feels India might not be able to capitalise on it the way the US or Asian peers like Indonesia and Vietnam seem likely to.

Solomon sees chances of a global recession in 2020 to be 'low'.

Despite long-term optimism, Solomon had one word of caution. “India is still a place where the regulatory impact on business slows economic growth.” An optimist who would rather unwind on the DJ console after a hard week's work, he added, “I am hopeful that that progress will continue and accelerate.”

Asked about changing regulatory goalposts in ecommerce and teething problems that hamper smooth implementation of new laws such as bankruptcy code, which in turn sends out mixed signals to global investors, Solomon argued that it is a commonplace practice around the world. “It's par for the course when you are driving change in a major economy. While I am sure there are investors who are frustrated and want things to go quicker, we take a very long-term view… goal posts in any economy can keep shifting, including the US.”

The changing regulatory environment around the world, especially surrounding technology and privacy issues, has also seen growing demand to split large technology companies like Facebook. Solomon, whose firm has a vice like grip on tech IPOs in the US, along with rivals Morgan Stanley, is against breaking them up. “Breaking up a company is a very, very difficult, complicated thing to do. Like any other business that becomes big and influential, Facebook will have to make adjustments,” he says. He does see chances of heightened government regulations “putting more rules, guard rails and parameters in place.”

A daily selection of the best exclusive reporting from S&P Global Market Intelligence.

Welcome to The Daily Intel, a roundup of exclusive news and analysis from S&P Global Market Intelligence, curated by our journalists.

Editor's Pick

US bank margins crushed in Q2, falling to record lows

U.S. banks' net interest margin fell to 2.74% in the second quarter from 3.16% in the first quarter as institutions found few opportunities to put excess liquidity to work outside the low-yielding credits associated with the federal government's small-business rescue program.

While the loans carry 1% rates, the credits are expected to bring fees of about 3% on average once loans are forgiven. But that is not expected to occur until the third or fourth quarter of 2020 or possibly 2021.

Healthcare

Largest healthcare deals of 2020 break through COVID-19 M&A drought

Two multibillion-dollar acquisitions in August Siemens Healthineers' acquisition of Varian and the Teladoc-Livongo tie-up broke a dry spell in dealmaking brought on by the COVID-19 pandemic, but the recovery is far from complete and health M&A activity is likely to remain sector-specific.

Financials

Banks battle PPP agent fees in court

U.S. banks are facing lawsuits from agents such as accountants, attorneys and loan brokers, who are seeking payment for services on Paycheck Protection Program loans, sometimes in cases where the lender did not know an agent was providing loan application services.

As 'big tech' dominates cloud use for banks, regulators may need to get tougher

Banks rely heavily on a small number of big tech companies for cloud infrastructure. This concentration of power in the hands of just a few providers creates risks for the financial sector, analysts told S&P Global Market Intelligence.

Landlords bracing for 'no-show' students as pandemic upends college reopenings

As the COVID-19 pandemic upends plans for in-person classes this school year, owners of student housing properties face an uncertain future. "I think the next three weeks are going to be crucial to see who actually shows up," said Suzanne Sorkin of Adelante Capital Management.

Energy and Utilities

US utilities, power providers advance plans to accelerate coal retirements

With demand for coal further depressed by the COVID-19 pandemic, multiple U.S. utilities hinted on earnings calls that they may soon announce plans to accelerate retirements in the aging U.S. coal fleet.

urn:contentItem:5VNP-SFW1-DXVP-V104-00000-00Lowry: Don't break up Big Tech2019-03-17T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:08:15ZLexisNexisOPINIONLowry: Don't break up Big TechRich Lowry

The worst ideas in Washington are often bipartisan. Big Tech is about to learn this lesson, if it hasn't already.

Elizabeth Warren is out with a headline-grabbing proposal to break up Big Tech companies, the sort of overly ambitious government plan that once would have engendered knee-jerk Republican opposition. Not anymore. Who says we all can't get along?

When the senator tweeted her (understandable) objection that Facebook had taken down her ads attacking Facebook and other tech companies, Ted Cruz agreed that the companies have too much power.

Tech is caught in a right-left pincer. Conservatives don't like these companies because they are owned and operated by sanctimonious Silicon Valley liberals subject to the worst sort of groupthink. Progressives don't like them because they are colossal profit-making enterprises.

That's why there is some chance Washington might get together and, along the lines Warren proposes, effectively outlaw the business models of some of the most successful and iconic American companies.

Warren's idea to cleave off the platforms of the tech companies and have them run as "platform utilities" separate from the rest of their business is unworkable and is justified by a series of errors and misjudgments.

It's not true, as Warren asserts, that the antitrust suit against Microsoft in the 1990s opened up the space for Google and Facebook to thrive. Microsoft never got the internet and left the space open for Google and Facebook all by itself, as often happens with a large incumbent wedded to its business model.

She charges that the tech companies use mergers to limit competition and cites Facebook's acquisition of WhatsApp. It's hard to discern the harm here. When the social network bought it, WhatsApp was available for a fee. Now it's free, and more people use it than ever. What's the problem?

She calls out Google for allegedly killing off its competitors by burying them in its searches. It's not obvious that Google actually does this, although its search business inherently involves constantly making choices to try to best serve what people want to see. No government regulator is going to improve Google's searches, or is qualified to even try.

Warren's proposal is obviously formulated without taking any account of the interests of consumers, who are the ones who made the tech companies so large.

Why does Google provide for free a tool without which it's impossible to imagine contemporary life? Because it can monetize it with advertising. Without the advertising, which Warren insists should be a separate business, Google has no incentive to devote engineers to improving its search engine.

By the same token, no one will welcome iPhones that no longer come with or sell Apple apps. And would people really appreciate having to go to two different Amazons, one just a platform, one selling Amazon products?

This is all silly, as are the mergers that Warren pledges to reverse, including Amazon's acquisition of Whole Foods. Amazon doesn't have anything close to a monopoly in food retail. Rather than taking over the sector, it's spurring investment and innovation. The nation's largest supermarket chain, Kroger, was slated to increase its spending on investment 200 percent in 2018.

The tech giants aren't stand-pat companies. Amazon alone spent more than $22 billion on investment in 2017. The development of autonomous vehicles, artificial intelligence and voice recognition wouldn't be nearly as advanced if it weren't for the research of the tech companies. The behemoth of yesteryear, General Electric, isn't making these investments.

None of this is to deny genuine concerns about tech companies. They need rules for content that honor the spirit of the First Amendment, and perhaps there should be tighter regulations around privacy. But any real offenses should be addressed with fixes directed at specific conduct, rather than with a massive politically imposed reorganization.

That's a very bad idea, and if you had any doubt, watch it get a respectful hearing from both sides in Washington.

Rich Lowry can be reached at comments.lowry@nationalreview.com

urn:contentItem:5X7V-X3G1-DXVP-V31M-00000-00Lowry: Elizabeth Warren's threat to the Constitution2019-10-10T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:08:15ZLexisNexisOPINIONLowry: Elizabeth Warren's threat to the ConstitutionRich Lowry

There's a brewing constitutional crisis, and it is the Elizabeth Warren surge in the Democratic primaries.

Should the Massachusetts senator become president of the United States, she will undertake a historic bout of federal activism unmoored from any serious consideration of constitutional constraints.

This would far exceed the current "constitutional crisis" over the Ukraine controversy. Impeachment involves the House of Representatives exercising a responsibility clearly bestowed on it with broad latitude by the U.S. Constitution, to punish an act by President Donald Trump that was foolish and improper, but also squarely within his constitutional powers.

House Speaker Nancy Pelosi likes to say Trump violated the Constitution on his call with the Ukrainian president, but there's no serious argument for this. The conduct of foreign policy -- and horse-trading with foreign leaders -- is a core presidential duty.

The problem was mingling personal political priorities with actions in his official capacity, a symptom of one of the worst aspects of Trump's presidency, namely his inability or unwillingness to distinguish between himself and his office. Trump doesn't think institutionally or constitutionally.

In contrast to his carelessness and highly personalized view of the presidency, Warren offers a carefully thought-out agenda of open contempt for legal and constitutional boundaries. It's not that she, a former Harvard Law professor, doesn't know that they exist; it's that she doesn't care.

Her broad approach is if she doesn't like something about America, she'll act as president to ban it or curtail it, whether she has the legal or constitutional authority or not. This isn't a trait personal to her. Instead, it is inherent to progressive government, which from its beginnings in the early 20th century strained against constitutional limits it considered antiquated and unnecessary.

One of Warren's signature domestic proposals is her wealth tax. Without dwelling on the complex legal arguments, her plan is constitutionally dubious, at best, and would instantly end up in the Supreme Court if it ever passed.

Someone scrupulously committed to the Constitution would want to steer clear on this basis alone, but "constitutionally or legally suspect" is the unifying thread of much of the Warren agenda.

As conservative writer David French points out, her proposed executive order prohibiting fracking obviously runs afoul of a 2005 federal law protecting it from federal regulation. She is promising to do something illegal, pure and simple.

And on it goes. She says she would act unilaterally to expand background checks for gun purchases, circumventing Congress. She wants to tax lobbying, an activity protected under the First Amendment, in yet another constitutionally fraught initiative. She wants to break up Big Tech, although it's not clear under what authority.

Tellingly, almost no one on her side says, "I appreciate what you're getting at Liz, but you can't do that."

To their credit, a couple of CNN panelists pressed her in July on the constitutional basis of her wealth tax, and she just waved them off. Needless to say, the op-ed pages and airwaves weren't thick with denunciations of her casual dismissal of the Constitution.

This gets to a marked, and annoying, hypocrisy in the reaction to Trump's Ukraine call. The same people who are most convinced that it is somehow unconstitutional or illegal didn't raise a peep when President Barack Obama rewrote immigration law on his own after repeatedly, and correctly, saying he didn't have the power to do it.

To be sure, the reliable, consistent constituency for strictly bounded executive action is vanishingly small. It amounts to about a dozen senators, those Republicans brave enough to oppose Trump's emergency declaration to repurpose military funding for the border wall, the most problematic of his executive actions.

All you need to know about how seriously most of the left takes the Constitution is that at the same time it's freaking out about Trump, it's boosting the prospects of Elizabeth Warren, who is promising to ignore it as a matter of policy.

Rich Lowry can be reached at comments.lowry@nationalreview.com
